results.title: Norma
results.creator_credit: William Fitzwater, Sandro Sequi, Australian Broadcasting Corporation and Australian Opera
results.brief_description: Norma, the opera by Bellini, libretto by Felice Romani, based on a drama by Alexandre Soumet and directed by Sandro Sequi, is set in Gaul during the Roman occupation about 50 BC. Norma, the Druid High priestess, sung by Dame Joan Sutherland, breaks her vows of chastity with the Roman Pollione, sung by Ron Stevens. In a tangled tale of love and tragedy, the two lovers pay the ultimate sacrifice for their love and die together. Features singers Clifford Grant (Oroveso), Trevor Brown (Flavio), Margreta Elkins (Adalgisa), Etela Piha (Clotilde), and The Australian Opera Chorus. Also features The Elizabethan Sydney Orchestra conducted by Richard Bonynge. Recorded at the Sydney Opera House on 1 August 1978 and produced for television in association with the Australian Broadcasting Corporation. Restored and released in 1991 by The Australian Opera. Sung in Italian with English subtitles.

results.title: Norm and Ahmed (Captioned)
results.creator_credit: Karl McPhee, Tristram Miall and Film Australia
results.brief_description: Twenty years after its creation, Norm and Ahmed, remains a classic in Australian literature. This video of the play features the well-known actor Max Cullen as Norm and Alex Pinder as Ahmed. The action centres on a midnight meeting between Norm, an average Australian, who embodies the ocker image and Ahmed, an urbane Pakistan student. The chance encounter starts off in a friendly enough manner, but underneath Norm’s veneer of mateyness lies a distrust of the unfamiliar and a defensiveness which turns nasty when Norm feels threatened. The themes of racism and prejudices in the play are still pertinent today.

results.title: Nomads
results.material_description: Single channel moving image, black and white and colour and audio
results.brief_description: Kalin’s short video works, which use literary quotations as starting points, function both as visual poems and as alternative music videos. With their astute conjunctions of image, music and text, these tapes respond to issues of sexuality and human interaction in the 1990s, more than a decade into the AIDS crisis. In Nomads, a brief text by Jane Bowles is the point of departure for a vivid music video that presents an elliptical view of the realities of contemporary urban life. ‘I fear nomads. I am afraid of them and afraid for them too.’ — Jane Bowles, Camp Cataract.

results.title: NOISE on film: noise for Darfur = Why should Australians make noise for Darfur?
results.creator_credit: Darfur Australia Network and Infinite Films
results.brief_description:
This documentary has been produced to raise awareness about the continuing tragedy in the Darfur region of Western Sudan and build solidarity between the Australian people and the people of Darfur.
The conflict in Darfur has been continuing for more than three years, has resulted in the deaths of more than 400,000 civilians, the displacement of at least 2.5 million people and there are currently 3.5 million people dependent upon insufficient international humanitarian aid. Darfur is in crisis and the genocide has to stop.
The film includes footage from refugee camps in Darfur, artwork and music from a range of local artists, and the perceptions of a range of influential Australians as to why Australians should make NOISE for Darfur.

results.title: Katharine Hepburn: all about me: a self portrait
results.creator_credit: David Heeley, Joan Kramer and Top Hat Productions
results.brief_description: One of the most respected and beloved of actresses, Katharine Hepburn presents a unique self-portrait using footage from her many films, never-before-seen home movie footage and personal memorabilia. Hepburn looks at the ups and downs of her career as well as taking the viewer on a personal journey. Her candour and commonsense approach have been representative of her dynamic personality, independence, integrity, determination and strength of character. In a Hollywood which was largely dominated by men, Katharine Hepburn was a woman to be reckoned with.
